title: Events Management: Starting Your Own Business
headline: This free online event management course equips you with the knowledge to start and run your own business.
description: This free online event planning course provides a useful foundation for anyone who wishes to start and manage their own event planning business. Learn about the requirements and industry standards you need to be aware of. Other valuable aspects covered in the course are promotion and ticketing strategies, logistics and team management. Finally, you will learn about the pros and cons of being your own boss and how to construct a business plan.
courseDescription:
This free online event planning business course will equip you with the skills required to start your business and manage your own events. You will begin with an overview of strategies to promote an event in order to attract traffic. You will also discover how to finance and develop realistic budgets for an event. Plus, you will learn ticketing tips about setting ticket prices, tiered ticketing and how to sell the tickets effectively.

Next you will learn about event themes, how they bring your event to life and how to work with suppliers. You will learn about theme staging and design and how to best use your venue of choice to make an event lively. You will be taught about various categories of suppliers and how to best engage, negotiate and work with them productively. You will also be taught how to troubleshoot various event activities and manage your team effectively.

Finally, you will be taught the steps you can follow to start your business of event management . You will learn about the difference between event planning and events management and the roles associated with each. You will learn how to draft a business plan and the best business banking packages and services to use for your financial planning. This event planning business course will help you determine if you are a good fit for a career in the events industry and give you an advantage over the competition. So why wait? Start learning today.

Finally, you will be taught the steps you can follow to start your own events planning business. You will learn about the difference between events planning and events management and the roles associated with each. You will learn how to draft a business plan and the best business banking packages and services to use for your financial planning. This course will help you determine if you are a good fit for a career in the events industry and give you an advantage over the competition. So why wait? Start learning today.

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Outline the different stages of event promotion.
    • Explain the use of social media to promote an event.
    • Describe the use of traditional media to promote an event.
    • Explain the use of social media to drive engagement at the event.
    • Describe the use of promotion to bring people back to an annual event.
    • Outline the importance of budgeting and financial management.
    • Describe how to successfully create a budget.
    • Identify typical event costs.
    • Outline how to set ticket prices.
    • Describe how to manage, promote and sell tickets.

  • Promoting the Event

  • Promoting your event is almost as important as creating a great event. Without effective promotion, you can put on a fantastic event but no one will come because they do not know about it.

    Event promotion is often labelled as a marketing effort. Most of these efforts are related to marketing events, charity events, concerts or any other type of event that you are actively trying to draw the general public to.

    However, event promotion does not begin and end with public events. Even private events need to have some type of promotion so that people know about it. With a private event, you will not be buying up ad space. 

    However, you might still choose to use the Internet to help ensure that the invited guests know about the event and to help drive engagement and interest in your event.

    In this module, you will learn more about the different steps that you can take to promote an event. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Rather than using this module as a cookie-cutter solution to event promotion, you should aim to learn about the different methods and how to apply them to individual events.

  • Promotion During Event

  • Promotion does not end when your event begins. Now that you have your attendees in one space, it is important to hold on to their interest all the way to the end of the event.

    • Your hashtag is just as important during the event as it is before the event. 

      Continue to promote its use as the event continues so that people can interact with each other while they are at the event. 

      Make sure that you interact with the hashtag, too. Leading by example is a good way to encourage others to use these resources.

      You should also be posting content while the event is running. Much of this content can be created beforehand and put into a social media schedule like HootSuite. 

      However, if there are real time events that are not anticipated, be sure to respond to these as well.

    • Contests are a great way to drive interaction and engagement during the event. 

      Once you have people captive, you can use a contest to help keep them engaged by asking for small tasks in exchange for big prizes.

      You can use contests at almost any type of event. For example, at a concert venue, you can send out a trivia question by Twitter. 

      The person who first comes up with the right answer on Twitter might win a VIP table or upgraded tickets.

  • Finances and Budgeting

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Finances and budgeting are important parts of planning any event. 

    Creativity, design and leadership are also important; however, if you do not have the money you need to pay your bills, a beautifully designed event just won’t happen.

  • One of the main reasons a person or company will hire you as an events planner is to make sure their budget is managed properly. They will rely on you to be well connected in the industry and know the best ways to spend money.

    This is because budgeting is not about being cheap or trying to spend as little money as possible. It is about value, or, getting the most from the money that you have.

    Your ability to manage the event’s finances will directly impact your ability to get and keep clients. 

    A healthy relationship with money is important, especially when you are dealing with someone else’s cash.

    Creativity, design and leadership are also important; however, if you do not have the money you need to pay your bills, a beautifully designed event just won’t happen.

  • One of the main reasons a person or company will hire you as an events planner is to make sure their budget is managed properly. They will rely on you to be well connected in the industry and know the best ways to spend money.

    This is because budgeting is not about being cheap or trying to spend as little money as possible. It is about value, or, getting the most from the money that you have.

    Your ability to manage the event’s finances will directly impact your ability to get and keep clients. 

    A healthy relationship with money is important, especially when you are dealing with someone else’s cash.

  • Managing Ticket Sales

  • Not every event you organise will require ticket sales. However, knowing how to manage ticket sales is a useful asset for any event planner because it will help you project and analyse event attendance.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Most tickets today are sold online because it is a paperless and inexpensive way to monitor sales.

    Events of all types and sizes can benefit from using online resources like EventBrite to monitor ticket sales because it does all of the selling, distribution and tracking for you.
  • You can even use these resources to send out messages to event attendees in the event that there are changes.

    Selling tickets online is also useful because it puts a third-party in charge of the ticket revenue. This can be useful because the third-party seller will often hold on to the revenue until after the event is over.

    Selling tickets online can make it easier in the unlikely event that refunds need to be issued.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Event promotion does not end when the event begins. 

    The best way to promote your event is to start early and promote often, though not so often that it becomes a full-time job. 

    Be sure to use both traditional and internet media sources to promote your event and do not rely only on self-promotion.

    Internet media sources include the use of email, an event website, social media and writing a blog.

    Event attendees will do a lot of this promotion for you if you put up a well-organized event. All you have to do is harness it.

    As an events planner, you will often be in charge of your client’s budget and finances.

    Good financial planning will help your client stay within budget which is one of your major goals.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Describe how to make the most of a venue’s resources.
    • Explain how to use seasonal themes.
    • Recognize how to incorporate themes into all types of events.
    • Explain ways to bring your event theme to life.
    • Outline the different suppliers that you will need.
    • Describe how to find reliable suppliers.
    • Identify how to hire suppliers.
    • Identify how to negotiate with your suppliers.
    • Outline the best practices for working with suppliers.

  • Bring the Theme to Life

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The best themes are comprehensive. They spill over into every area of your event from the food to the decorations to the music.

    It is not enough to simply plan a theme and order supplies. 

    To create an exceptional theme, you also need to find unique and individual ways to bring this theme to life. 
  • There are a lot of variables that go into creating a theme that captures the imagination of your guests.

    It all starts with finding the right name for the event. Some corporate events will be simple because they will already have a standard name picked out. 

    However, when you have the chance to name the event yourself, you want to make sure your name matches the overall theme.

  • Working with Suppliers

  • After you have interviewed the right supplier, you need to make a decision about hiring them. However, there is one more step that you should go through before money exchanges hands.

    It is best to have a conversation about what it will be like when you are working together.

    You want to do this after the interview because you first want a strong indication of what their capabilities are. This can be muddled if you start talking business immediately during the interview.

    During this conversation, you want to be clear about what you want your working relationship to be like. If you have specific requirements or requests, it is best to outline them here and now.

    If the supplier has specific requests, you should encourage them to outline them here, too.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The more you know about working together, the easier it will be to ensure that your relationship goes smoothly.

  • Lesson Summary

  • A well-executed theme transforms an event from a day into a memory. Design and staging can go a long way toward helping your guests remember your event fondly. As an event planner, it is important to analyse the venue of the event.

    Keep a full inventory of the venue features as they present opportunities and challenges in the event theming and planning process.In addition to planning a theme, you can bring your event to life by finding the right name, creating a suitable colour scheme, use of flowers and plants, blending furniture and extending the theme to the food.

    Your clients will rely on your design capabilities. Because of the creative flair and the number of details that go into it, this can be one of the most challenging parts of planning an event. It is important to create a comprehensive and emotive theme to wow your guests and your clients every time.

    The key to working with great suppliers is building up a good relationship with them. Remember that this relationship begins with the first point of contact and does not end when the job is over.

    Every step of the process is an opportunity to strengthen both your relationship with your suppliers and your business.

    When you are searching for suppliers, remember that working together is not a one-way street. Attracting great suppliers to your team requires you to be the kind of person that people want to work with.

    Keep a full inventory of the venue features as they present opportunities and challenges in the event theming and planning process.In addition to planning a theme, you can bring your event to life by finding the right name, creating a suitable colour scheme, use of flowers and plants, blending furniture and extending the theme to the food.

    Your clients will rely on your design capabilities. Because of the creative flair and the number of details that go into it, this can be one of the most challenging parts of planning an event. It is important to create a comprehensive and emotive theme to wow your guests and your clients every time.

    The key to working with great suppliers is building up a good relationship with them. Remember that this relationship begins with the first point of contact and does not end when the job is over.

    Every step of the process is an opportunity to strengthen both your relationship with your suppliers and your business.

    When you are searching for suppliers, remember that working together is not a one-way street. Attracting great suppliers to your team requires you to be the kind of person that people want to work with.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain how to manage the event space and the parking facilities.
    • Recognize the impact of electricity on your event space.
    • Describe the organization of sound for the event.
    • Describe how to layout furniture and tents.
    • Explain how to dispose of waste during an event.
    • Outline the different types of event staff.
    • Explain the process of hiring event staff.
    • Explain the process of training event staff.
    • Identify the role of a manager.
    • Explain how to lead an event team.

  • Troubleshooting

  • In an ideal world, thoughtful planning will help any event run smoothly. Realistically, you can expect to run into problems no matter how detailed your preparations are. There will always be a chance of equipment failing or a caterer letting you down.

    The good news is that with smart planning, you will be able to prevent many of these problems before they happen.  Planning also helps you efficiently deal with the problems that do arise on the day of the event. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • If you have a great backup plan, guests never need to know there was ever a problem at all.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Having a solid logistics plan is necessary not only for the success of your event but for the health and safety of your guests, vendors and team.

    Before you choose a space for your event, you must consider whether you want to host the event indoors or outdoors.

    If you’re hiring an outdoor space, you have the right provisions for keeping everyone safe and happy. This is important in case of changing weather conditions. You will also need to consider whether there is space for parking, portaloos, stages, and marquees if need be.

    When you are hosting an indoor event, you will need to consider the maximum occupancy of the room or building that you hire. Tables, chairs and any other furniture should always be set up in a manner that is suitable for health and safety.

    Other key factors to consider include event electricity and sound. In addition to leading your suppliers, you will also likely be leading a team. The most common roles you will need to fill include, assistants, hosts, servers support staff and tech support.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • List the pros and cons of running an events planning business.
    • Explain the responsibilities of being a self-employed events planner.
    • Describe the approach you should take to your business.
    • Explain how to write a business plan.
    • Discuss business bank accounts.

  • Starting Your Own Business

  • Starting your own business is an exciting thing. Finally, you have the freedom to choose your projects, your hours and your own happiness. This freedom is what most of us long for and you are about to achieve it. However, freedom comes at a price. Whether you’re self-employed or intend to incorporate, your roles and responsibilities are about to change dramatically.

    Starting your own business is a lot of work. All that work needs to happen before you even begin working with clients! The amount of work required often comes down to what kind of events you want to plan and who you want to plan them for. Planning birthday parties has less overheads than trying to plan the next Glastonbury.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • In this module, you will learn more about the scope of the work involved and the equipment you will need. Again, all of this will depend on how big you want your business to be.
  • For sole traders, it is possible to start with a few supplies and work for a handful of clients. For those offering a more comprehensive service, you may find that you have a few more hoops to jump through when setting up shop.

  • Writing a Business Plan

  • If you’ve ever thought about starting a business in the past, it is the act of writing a business plan that might have put you off. However, even if you know what you’re going to do and how you’re going to do it, you still need one. Some people do succeed without having a plan.

    However, these people are the exception and not the rule. Having a business plan significantly increases your chances for success.The first rule of writing a business plan is to be realistic. Too many business plans are fantasies. Your plan should not convince other people of your potential. It should be used as a tool to help convince you that your ideas are realistic and achievable. Your business plan is not a grand plan; it is an organisational tool for you to rely on.

    Your business plan should be the guide for your business operation, at least for the first few months. It should work as a plan that you can follow to make sure you are moving in the right direction to achieve your goals. Your business plan should include your vision and your purpose. Many first time business owners are unconvinced of the need to carefully craft a company vision. However, these things are vital for your business. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The final rule for creating your business plan is the financial proposal. You will use this part of the business plan when you go to the bank or if you’re looking for investors. It should outline a realistic projection of your finances.

  • Writing a Business Plan

  • If you’ve ever thought about starting a business in the past, it is the act of writing a business plan that might have put you off. However, even if you know what you’re going to do and how you’re going to do it, you still need one. Some people do succeed without having a plan.

    However, these people are the exception and not the rule. Having a business plan significantly increases your chances for success.The first rule of writing a business plan is to be realistic. Too many business plans are fantasies. Your plan should not convince other people of your potential. It should be used as a tool to help convince you that your ideas are realistic and achievable. Your business plan is not a grand plan; it is an organisational tool for you to rely on.

    Your business plan should be the guide for your business operation, at least for the first few months.   • Lesson Summary

  • Running an events planning business has its own pros and cons. 

    Pros: you get to determine your own schedule, start up is simple and investment cost is low. 

    Cons: the industry is competitive, it's a big responsibility, you are in charge of your own taxes, sick pay, and maternity benefits and taking time off can be difficult.

    A self-employed events planner is in charge of administrative and marketing costs.

    Your responsibilities include taxes and liability insurance for your own safety and the safety of your clients.

    You need to decide which approach to the industry that you would like to take: events planner, events manager or a combination role.

    Events planners: creative, good at charming with clients, marketing and planning skills, wants several employees and has a knack for accounting and taxes.

    Events managers: skilled at dealing with inventory, leadership skills, logistical problem solvers, people person, multi-tasker and energetic.
